title: Homograph fix Bypass

profile.name: HackerOne
profile.about: Vulnerability disclosure should be safe, transparent, and rewarding.

vulnerability_information:
Hello Hackerone!
I have possibly found a way to bypass your current Homograph Attack Fix.

Lets look at two HACKERONE Redirect URL:
CASE 1:
https://hackerone.com/redirect?signature=829727b4188c43dcf394fd841fd19a8b7f391bd1&url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.yelp.com%2F

{****Got the above link generated by posting "https://www.yelp.com/" on Hackerone Platform****}

If I change even a single character in the URL parameter above the link gets Invalid. We get "Something went wrong" Response. 
For Example (try changing yelp.com to yelk.com)
https://hackerone.com/redirect?signature=829727b4188c43dcf394fd841fd19a8b7f391bd1&url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.yelk.com%2F


Now Lets look at a sample Hackerone Redirect URL of a IDN HOMOGRAPH Link:

CASE 2:

https://hackerone.com/redirect?signature=e021a53caee6e288347ad14e95648ba6d8fb53cb&url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.xn--elp-cfd.com%2F

{***Got this link generated by posting https://www.уelp.com/ on hackerone platform.  NOTE: Here "уelp.com" is actually an IDN and its punycode version is "xn--elp-cfd.com" & that's why it automatically got converted by Hackerone to its punycode representation in the above URL****}

Now lets replace "xn--elp-cfd.com" to the original IDN i.e "уelp.com" in the above URL.

As Infered from CASE 1, Upon changing any character in the URL parameter, Ideally we should get an error and the link should become invalid.

But,that is not the case here when we are dealing with IDN Links. The link is still valid even after changing value of the URL parameter-From Punycode version to IDN.

Have a look at the changed URL here:
https://hackerone.com/redirect?signature=e021a53caee6e288347ad14e95648ba6d8fb53cb&url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.%D1%83elp.com%2F

***NOTE: Till Now the External Link Warning Page Displays : "https://www.xn--elp-cfd.com/"***

Now, IF we Add extra "//" after "https:%3A%2F%2F" in the above url we get the following URL:

https://hackerone.com/redirect?signature=e021a53caee6e288347ad14e95648ba6d8fb53cb&url=https%3A%2F%2F//www.%D1%83elp.com%2F

***You can see that the above link displays "https:///www.yelp.com/" but actually redirects us to "https://www.xn--elp-cfd.com/" ***

And thus the current fix for Homograph attack seems to be bypassed. Mobile phone users are more likely to be affected by the above vulnerability.
vulnerability_information_html:
Hello Hackerone!
I have possibly found a way to bypass your current Homograph Attack Fix.

Lets look at two HACKERONE Redirect URL:
CASE 1:
https://hackerone.com/redirect?signature=829727b4188c43dcf394fd841fd19a8b7f391bd1&url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.yelp.com%2F

{*Got the above link generated by posting "https://www.yelp.com/" on Hackerone Platform*}

If I change even a single character in the URL parameter above the link gets Invalid. We get "Something went wrong" Response.
For Example (try changing yelp.com to yelk.com)
https://hackerone.com/redirect?signature=829727b4188c43dcf394fd841fd19a8b7f391bd1&url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.yelk.com%2F

Now Lets look at a sample Hackerone Redirect URL of a IDN HOMOGRAPH Link:

CASE 2:

https://hackerone.com/redirect?signature=e021a53caee6e288347ad14e95648ba6d8fb53cb&url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.xn--elp-cfd.com%2F

{Got this link generated by posting https://www.xn--elp-cfd.com/ on hackerone platform. NOTE: Here "уelp.com" is actually an IDN and its punycode version is "xn--elp-cfd.com" & that's why it automatically got converted by Hackerone to its punycode representation in the above URL*}

Now lets replace "xn--elp-cfd.com" to the original IDN i.e "уelp.com" in the above URL.

As Infered from CASE 1, Upon changing any character in the URL parameter, Ideally we should get an error and the link should become invalid.

But,that is not the case here when we are dealing with IDN Links. The link is still valid even after changing value of the URL parameter-From Punycode version to IDN.

Have a look at the changed URL here:
https://hackerone.com/redirect?signature=e021a53caee6e288347ad14e95648ba6d8fb53cb&url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.%D1%83elp.com%2F

NOTE: Till Now the External Link Warning Page Displays : "https://www.xn--elp-cfd.com/"

Now, IF we Add extra "//" after "https:%3A%2F%2F" in the above url we get the following URL:

https://hackerone.com/redirect?signature=e021a53caee6e288347ad14e95648ba6d8fb53cb&url=https%3A%2F%2F//www.%D1%83elp.com%2F

**You can see that the above link displays "https:///www.yelp.com/" but actually redirects us to "https://www.xn--elp-cfd.com/" **

And thus the current fix for Homograph attack seems to be bypassed. Mobile phone users are more likely to be affected by the above vulnerability.

activities.message:
@wvdv @coffeecup  

Okay. Apart from this homograph bypass, there's one more vulnerability in the external warning URL page that caught my eye recently. 

                              DESCRIPTION & ADDITIONAL INFORMATION:

I was planning to report it as separate issue.

But as that could also be fixed along with the above issue I decided to post it as a comment here itself. Its up to you to decide both of these as separate or as a combined report. Proceeding further, Here's what i found:

 Lets have a look at the URI scheme:

scheme:[//[user[:password]@]host[:port]][/path][?query][#fragment]

You may infer that something like "http://user:pass@xyz.com" would authenticate us to xyz.com with user=user and password=pass.


Now, have a look at the following URL:

http://1222222222/  
It's not like the usual URL you may see. It takes us to :
https://72.217.161.142/

{ Note: 1222222222  is the decimal conversion of the IP address 72.217.161.142. A Decimal converted IP address could be used by the browser to visit the IP address. }

So, from the above we can see that something like :

https://xyz.com@1222222222/ 

when given to the browser would try to authenticate us with username="xyz.com"  on the IP address 1222222222 i.e 
72.217.161.142

                                        EXPLOIT OR POC:

I posted such a URL on the hackerone.com platform.

Please visit the Following URL:

https://hackerone.com/redirect?signature=d674772ce6d1c337debe8fee906b0fa5a03f69ca&url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.hackerone.com%401222222222%2Freports%2F12332

You would find that the "1222222222" is marked as red in the field, which demonstrates that "1222222222" is the main domain the user is going to visit. 

Now, 

I tried to change any of the characters in the above URL but that makes the link invalid. 
Now, When we try to add extra "//" in the url parameter above we find:

https://hackerone.com/redirect?signature=d674772ce6d1c337debe8fee906b0fa5a03f69ca&url=https%3A%2F%2F//www.hackerone.com%401222222222%2Freports%2F12332

The red mark is removed and a typical user/team member/admin is most likely to fall for this attack.

                                     SAMPLE ATTACK SCENARIO:

The poor victim clicks on the link to open a webpage (thinking of visiting "hackerone.com" ) that is controlled by the attacker.
The attacker most probably has hosted some website similar to hackerone.com's main login page & displays a fake error message indicating "You have be logged out. Signin again to continue."

The attacker then exploits the victim to gain unauthorized access to the victim/users/team member/admin accounts.

                                         MITIGATION:

Combining these two reports we can infer that the main problem has arised because the external warning link page allowed us to edit some content of the URL. i.e:

Ability to Interchange Punycode to Unicode in the first report
&
Ability to add extra "//" in the second one.

So, the most probable fix that i think should be :

Enforcing strict length based restriction on the complete redirect URL. i.e Storing the length of the URL while creating such links & checking it everytime the link is requested again. 
& Disallowing any additional characters like "//".


Although Hackerone.com has previously worked for some mitigations on this but the above two reports seems to a bypass for the current protection mechanism. 

PLEASE RECOMMEND IF I NEED TO REPORT THIS AS AN SEPARATE ISSUE

THANKS
activities.markdown_message:
@wvdv @coffeecup

Okay. Apart from this homograph bypass, there's one more vulnerability in the external warning URL page that caught my eye recently. 

                          DESCRIPTION & ADDITIONAL INFORMATION:

I was planning to report it as separate issue.

But as that could also be fixed along with the above issue I decided to post it as a comment here itself. Its up to you to decide both of these as separate or as a combined report. Proceeding further, Here's what i found:

Lets have a look at the URI scheme:

scheme:[//[user[:password]@]host[:port]][/path][?query][#fragment]

You may infer that something like "http://user:pass@xyz.com" would authenticate us to xyz.com with user=user and password=pass.

Now, have a look at the following URL:

http://1222222222/

It's not like the usual URL you may see. It takes us to :
https://72.217.161.142/

{ Note: 1222222222 is the decimal conversion of the IP address 72.217.161.142. A Decimal converted IP address could be used by the browser to visit the IP address. }

So, from the above we can see that something like :

https://xyz.com@1222222222/

when given to the browser would try to authenticate us with username="xyz.com" on the IP address 1222222222 i.e
72.217.161.142

                                    EXPLOIT OR POC:

I posted such a URL on the hackerone.com platform.

Please visit the Following URL:

https://hackerone.com/redirect?signature=d674772ce6d1c337debe8fee906b0fa5a03f69ca&url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.hackerone.com%401222222222%2Freports%2F12332

You would find that the "1222222222" is marked as red in the field, which demonstrates that "1222222222" is the main domain the user is going to visit.

Now,

I tried to change any of the characters in the above URL but that makes the link invalid.
Now, When we try to add extra "//" in the url parameter above we find:

https://hackerone.com/redirect?signature=d674772ce6d1c337debe8fee906b0fa5a03f69ca&url=https%3A%2F%2F//www.hackerone.com%401222222222%2Freports%2F12332

The red mark is removed and a typical user/team member/admin is most likely to fall for this attack.

                                 SAMPLE ATTACK SCENARIO:

The poor victim clicks on the link to open a webpage (thinking of visiting "hackerone.com" ) that is controlled by the attacker.
The attacker most probably has hosted some website similar to hackerone.com's main login page & displays a fake error message indicating "You have be logged out. Signin again to continue."

The attacker then exploits the victim to gain unauthorized access to the victim/users/team member/admin accounts.

                                     MITIGATION:

Combining these two reports we can infer that the main problem has arised because the external warning link page allowed us to edit some content of the URL. i.e:

Ability to Interchange Punycode to Unicode in the first report
&
Ability to add extra "//" in the second one.

So, the most probable fix that i think should be :

Enforcing strict length based restriction on the complete redirect URL. i.e Storing the length of the URL while creating such links & checking it everytime the link is requested again.
& Disallowing any additional characters like "//".

Although Hackerone.com has previously worked for some mitigations on this but the above two reports seems to a bypass for the current protection mechanism.

PLEASE RECOMMEND IF I NEED TO REPORT THIS AS AN SEPARATE ISSUE

THANKS

activities.message: Any Updates from your side? It seems to be fixed now :)
activities.markdown_message: Any Updates from your side? It seems to be fixed now :)

activities.message:
Hey @hk755a,

We added two fixes: 

1): We fixed a bug where any URL with more than three slashes (e.g. `https:////`) was not correctly being updated to `https://`:
{F227791}
2): We added a warning to any urls for which we can't figure out what the domain is (this we did to harden against future issues in the parser):
{F227792}

Thanks for making HackerOne more secure!
activities.markdown_message:
Hey @hk755a,

We added two fixes:

1): We fixed a bug where any URL with more than three slashes (e.g. https:////) was not correctly being updated to https://:

2): We added a warning to any urls for which we can't figure out what the domain is (this we did to harden against future issues in the parser):

Thanks for making HackerOne more secure!

activities.message:
@dirk 
There's still a bypass :p

I have added a "%09" after "https" in the "url" parameter below :
https://hackerone.com/redirect?signature=e021a53caee6e288347ad14e95648ba6d8fb53cb&url=https%09%3A%2F%2Fwww.уelp.com%2F

And it again shows "yelp.com" in the external warning link.

activities.message: Hi @hk755a - We're looking into this. Thanks for bringing to our attention. We will update this report when we have additional info to share.

activities.message:
hey @hk755a,

Great bypass, looks like we missed a situation where URL parsing is just _completely_ broken, we're pushing a fix for this situation now! Thanks for the thorough validation!

Dirk

hey @hk755a,

activities.message: @hk755a - This has been pushed and is now live. Are you able to reproduce this issue or find a bypass again? If not, please let us know and we will mark this as resolved, thanks again for your report!

activities.message: Thank you for your report @hk755a - We are awarding you a $500 bounty with a bonus of $250 because you were able to find a bypass to our original fix. We look forward to more reports from you in the future! Thanks for hacking HackerOne!
activities.markdown_message: Thank you for your report @hk755a - We are awarding you a $500 bounty with a bonus of $250 because you were able to find a bypass to our original fix. We look forward to more reports from you in the future! Thanks for hacking HackerOne!
